001package com.technototes.library.command;
002
003import androidx.annotation.Nullable;
004
005import java.util.HashMap;
006import java.util.LinkedHashSet;
007import java.util.Map;
008import java.util.Set;
009import java.util.function.BooleanSupplier;
010
011import com.technototes.library.general.Periodic;
012import com.technototes.library.structure.CommandOpMode;
013import com.technototes.library.subsystem.Subsystem;
014
015/**
016 * This is a "singleton" object for scheduling commands. Most usage originates from {@link Command}
017 * methods {@link Command#andThen} or {@link Command#alongWith} for example. Outside of
018 * those usages, you will typically use {@code CommandScheduler.getInstance().scheduleJoystick} to
019 * control a drivebase.
020 *
021 * <p>
022 * TODO: The "CommandScheduler.getInstance()" thing is really kinda silly. Perhaps it's how WPIlib
023 * TODO: works, but it's clunky and makes things messier for non-FRC programmers. I think I'm going
024 * TODO: yoink that method and make static methods for next year's release...
025 */
026public final class CommandScheduler {
027
028    private final Map<Command, BooleanSupplier> commandMap;
029    private final Map<Subsystem, Set<Command>> requirementMap;
030    private final Map<Subsystem, Command> defaultMap;
031
032    private final Set<Periodic> registered;
033
034    private CommandOpMode opMode;
035
036    /**
037     * Set the scheduler's opmode
038     *
039     * @param c the opmode
040     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
041     */
042    public CommandScheduler setOpMode(CommandOpMode c) {
043        opMode = c;
044        return this;
045    }
046
047    /**
048     * Forcefully halt the opmode
049     *
050     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
051     */
052    public CommandScheduler terminateOpMode() {
053        opMode.terminate();
054        return this;
055    }
056
057    /**
058     * Gets the number of seconds that the opmode has been executing
059     *
060     * @return elapsed time since opmode was started, in seconds
061     */
062    public double getOpModeRuntime() {
063        return opMode.getOpModeRuntime();
064    }
065
066    // The Singleton CommandScheduler
067    private static CommandScheduler instance;
068
069    /**
070     * Get (or create) the singleton CommandScheduler object
071     *
072     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton
073     */
074    public static synchronized CommandScheduler getInstance() {
075        if (instance == null) {
076            instance = new CommandScheduler();
077        }
078        return instance;
079    }
080
081    /**
082     * Alex had a comment "be careful with this" and he's not wrong.
083     * This removes the old Singleton and creates a new one. That's pretty dangerous...
084     *
085     * @return a *new* singleton object (which makes very little sense)
086     */
087    public static synchronized CommandScheduler resetScheduler() {
088        instance = null;
089        Command.clear();
090        return getInstance();
091    }
092
093    private CommandScheduler() {
094        commandMap = new HashMap<>();
095        requirementMap = new HashMap<>();
096        defaultMap = new HashMap<>();
097        registered = new LinkedHashSet<>();
098    }
099
100    /**
101     * Schedule a command to run
102     *
103     * @param command the command to schedule
104     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
105     */
106    public CommandScheduler schedule(Command command) {
107        return schedule(command, () -> true);
108    }
109
110    /**
111     * Schedule a command to run
112     *
113     * @param command the command to schedule
114     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
115     */
116    public CommandScheduler scheduleOnce(Command command) {
117        return schedule(command);
118    }
119
120    /**
121     * Schedule a command to run during a particular OpModeState
122     *
123     * @param command the command to schedule
124     * @param state   the state during which the command should be scheduled
125     * @return the CommandScheduler (useful for chaining)
126     */
127    public CommandScheduler scheduleOnceForState(Command command, CommandOpMode.OpModeState state) {
128        return scheduleForState(command, state);
129    }
130
131    /**
132     * Schedule a command to be run recurringly during the 'Init' phase of an opmode.
133     * This can be used for vision, as well as running any system to help the
134     * drive team ensure that the robot is appropriately positioned on the field.
135     * This will only be run if the BooleanSupplier 'supplier' is also true!
136     *
137     * @param command  The command to run
138     * @param supplier The condition which also must be true to run the command
139     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
140     */
141    public CommandScheduler scheduleInit(Command command, BooleanSupplier supplier) {
142        return scheduleForState(command, supplier, CommandOpMode.OpModeState.INIT);
143    }
144
145    /**
146     * Schedule a command to be run recurringly during the 'Init' phase of an opmode.
147     * This can be used for vision, as well as running any system to help the
148     * drive team ensure that the robot is appropriately positioned on the field.
149     *
150     * @param command The command to run
151     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
152     */
153    public CommandScheduler scheduleInit(Command command) {
154        return scheduleForState(command, () -> true, CommandOpMode.OpModeState.INIT);
155    }
156
157    /**
158     * Schedules a command to be run during Run and End states, all the time.
159     * This is called "Schedule for Joystick" because joysticks don't really have a
160     * condition you might consider 'useful for triggering', so the command
161     * just runs repeatedly. This adds the requirement that the BooleanSupplier function
162     * is also true for the command to be run.
163     *
164     * @param command  The command to run repeatedly
165     * @param supplier The condition which must also be true to run the command
166     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
167     */
168    public CommandScheduler scheduleJoystick(Command command, BooleanSupplier supplier) {
169        return scheduleForState(command, supplier, CommandOpMode.OpModeState.RUN, CommandOpMode.OpModeState.END);
170    }
171
172    /**
173     * Schedules a command to be run during Run and End states, all the time.
174     * This is called "Schedule for Joystick" because joysticks don't really have a
175     * condition you might consider 'useful for triggering', so the command
176     * just runs repeatedly
177     *
178     * @param command The command to run repeatedly.
179     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
180     */
181    public CommandScheduler scheduleJoystick(Command command) {
182        return scheduleForState(command, CommandOpMode.OpModeState.RUN, CommandOpMode.OpModeState.END);
183    }
184
185    /**
186     * Schedule a command to be run when the OpMode is one of the provided list of states and the
187     * 'supplier' boolean function is also true.
188     *
189     * @param command  The command to run
190     * @param states   The list of states to schedule the command
191     * @param supplier The function to determin in the command should be scheduled
192     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
193     */
194    public CommandScheduler scheduleForState(
195            Command command, BooleanSupplier supplier, CommandOpMode.OpModeState... states) {
196        return schedule(
197                command.cancelUpon(() -> !opMode.getOpModeState().isState(states)),
198                () -> supplier.getAsBoolean() && opMode.getOpModeState().isState(states));
199    }
200
201    /**
202     * Schedule a command to be run when the OpMode is one of the provided list of states.
203     *
204     * @param command The command to run
205     * @param states  The list of states to schedule the command
206     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
207     */
208    public CommandScheduler scheduleForState(Command command, CommandOpMode.OpModeState... states) {
209        return schedule(
210                command.cancelUpon(() -> !opMode.getOpModeState().isState(states)),
211                () -> opMode.getOpModeState().isState(states));
212    }
213
214    /**
215     * Schedule the 'other' command (the second one) when the 'dependency' command has
216     * finished (but *not* been cancelled!).
217     *
218     * @param dependency The command upon which 'other' depends
219     * @param other      The command to schedule when 'dependency' has finished
220     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
221     */
222    public CommandScheduler scheduleAfterOther(Command dependency, Command other) {
223        return schedule(other, dependency::justFinishedNoCancel);
224    }
225
226    /**
227     * Schedule the 'other' command (the second one) when the 'dependency' command has
228     * just started.
229     *
230     * @param dependency The command upon which 'other' depends
231     * @param other      The command to schedule when 'dependency' has started
232     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
233     */
234    public CommandScheduler scheduleWithOther(Command dependency, Command other) {
235        return schedule(other, dependency::justStarted);
236    }
237
238    /**
239     * Schedule the 'other' command (the second one) when the 'dependency' command has
240     * finished (but *not* been cancelled!) *and* 'additionalCondition' is true.
241     *
242     * @param dependency          The command upon which 'other' depends
243     * @param other               The command to schedule when 'dependency' has finished
244     * @param additionalCondition The additional condition necessary to be true to schedule the 'other' command
245     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
246     */
247    public CommandScheduler scheduleAfterOther(Command dependency, Command other, BooleanSupplier additionalCondition) {
248        return schedule(other, () -> dependency.justFinishedNoCancel() && additionalCondition.getAsBoolean());
249    }
250
251    /**
252     * Schedule the 'other' command (the second one) when the 'dependency' command has
253     * just started *and* 'additionalCondition' is also true.
254     *
255     * @param dependency          The command upon which 'other' depends
256     * @param other               The command to schedule when 'dependency' has started
257     * @param additionalCondition The additional condition necessary to be true to schedule the 'other' command
258     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
259     */
260    public CommandScheduler scheduleWithOther(Command dependency, Command other, BooleanSupplier additionalCondition) {
261        return schedule(other, () -> dependency.justStarted() && additionalCondition.getAsBoolean());
262    }
263
264    /**
265     * Schedule the default command for a given subsystem. The default command will be run
266     * if no other command is currently running on that subsystem.
267     *
268     * @param command   The command to be run when others aren't using that subsystem
269     * @param subsystem The subsystem to run the command against when it's unused
270     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
271     */
272    public CommandScheduler scheduleDefault(Command command, Subsystem subsystem) {
273        if (command.getRequirements().contains(subsystem)) {
274            defaultMap.put(subsystem, command);
275            schedule(command, () -> getCurrent(subsystem) == command);
276        } else {
277            System.err.println("default commands must require their subsystem: "
278                    + command.getClass().toString());
279        }
280        return this;
281    }
282
283    /**
284     * Register a periodic function to be run once each schedule loop
285     *
286     * @param p The Periodic function to run
287     * @return The CommandScheduler singleton for chaining
288     */
289    public CommandScheduler register(Periodic p) {
290        registered.add(p);
291        return this;
292    }
293
294    /**
295     * Get the default command that is running on the subsystem provided
296     *
297     * @param s The subsystem in question
298     * @return the default command for the subsystem, or null if there is none
299     */
300    @Nullable
301    public Command getDefault(Subsystem s) {
302        return opMode.getOpModeState() == CommandOpMode.OpModeState.RUN ? defaultMap.get(s) : null;
303    }
304
305    /**
306     * This gets the command currently using the subsystem provided
307     *
308     * @param s The subsystem in question.
309     * @return The Command currently using the subsystem, the default
310     * command for the subsystem, or null if there is no current
311     * command usint the subsystem, nor a default command
312     */
313    @Nullable
314    public Command getCurrent(Subsystem s) {
315        if (requirementMap.get(s) == null) return null;
316        for (Command c : requirementMap.get(s)) {
317            if (c.isRunning()) return c;
318        }
319        return getDefault(s);
320    }
321
322    /**
323     * Register a command to be scheduled. The 'supplier' function is what triggers
324     * the schedule to begin running the command.
325     *
326     * @param command  The command to schedule
327     * @param supplier The function that returns true when the command should be run
328     * @return the CommandScheduler singleton for easy chaining
329     */
330    public CommandScheduler schedule(Command command, BooleanSupplier supplier) {
331        commandMap.put(command, supplier);
332        for (Subsystem s : command.getRequirements()) {
333            requirementMap.putIfAbsent(s, new LinkedHashSet<>());
334            requirementMap.get(s).add(command);
335            register(s);
336        }
337        return this;
338    }
339
340    /**
341     * This is invoked from inside the CommandOpMode method, during the opCode.
342     * It it the core logic of actually scheduling &amp; running the commands.
343     */
344    public void run() {
345        // For each newly scheduled command,
346        // cancel any existing command that is using the new command's subsystem requirements
347        commandMap.forEach((c1, b) -> {
348            if (c1.justStarted()) {
349                for (Subsystem s : c1.getRequirements()) {
350                    for (Command c2 : requirementMap.get(s)) {
351                        if (c1 != c2) {
352                            c2.cancel();
353                        }
354                    }
355                }
356            }
357        });
358        commandMap.forEach((c1, b) -> {
359            if (b.getAsBoolean() || c1.isRunning()) {
360                c1.run();
361            }
362        });
363        registered.forEach(Periodic::periodic);
364    }
365}
